user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of check_argument_match:
```c
static bool
check_argument_match (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                      char *args)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  struct test_header_param param;

  param.connection = connection;
  param.num_headers = 0;
  ret = MHD_parse_arguments_ (connection,
                              MHD_GET_ARGUMENT_KIND,
                              args,
                              &test_header,
                              &param);
  if (MHD_NO == ret)
  {
    return false;
  }
  /* also check that the number of headers matches */
  for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
  {
    if (MHD_GET_ARGUMENT_KIND != pos->kind)
      continue;
    param.num_headers--;
  }
  if (0 != param.num_headers)
  {
    /* argument count mismatch */
    return false;
  }
  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The fragments selected cover control-flow points that can lead to code being effectively unreachable (the function as a whole if the static function is never referenced, conditional early return after the external call, the loop/body that depends on runtime data, the post-loop conditional return, and the final return). Other parts of the function do not need investigation for Rule 2.1: simple declarations (struct/enum/local variables) and the two straightforward initializations of param are not themselves unreachable code; the call expression assigning ret is an external function call whose possible return paths are already represented by the checked conditional (and so investigation should focus on the conditional outcome rather than the call statement itself); there are no hidden goto/label constructs or subsequent statements after unconditional returns outside the listed fragments that would create additional unreachable code. Therefore only the listed control-flow fragments warrant further investigation for potential unreachable code.
